user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_register_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_register_generic(struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem)
{
	/* Make sure that we can be found. */
	metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);

	/* Statically registered shmem regions cannot have a destructor. */
	metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close);

	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list,
			    &shmem->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_shmem_register_generic:
#define metal_assert(cond) metal_sys_assert(cond)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the provided snippet: metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close) is a conditional runtime check and does not itself produce unreachable code — the following metal_list_add_tail(...) and return 0 can be reached when the assertion condition holds. A violation would occur only if metal_sys_assert (the macro expansion) unconditionally prevented normal flow (for example if it expanded to an unconditional non‑returning call or infinite loop such as abort() or for(;;) regardless of the condition). Given only the provided definition metal_assert(cond) -> metal_sys_assert(cond) and no evidence that metal_sys_assert unconditionally terminates, Rule 2.1 is not violated.
